INADMISSIBILITY OF ALIENS IDENTIFIED IN TERRORIST SCREENING DATABASE." is a condensed summary of the section discussing the inadmissibility of aliens identified in the terrorist screening database. Section 212(a)(3)(B)(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include aliens identified in the terrorist screening database as inadmissible, except for those lawfully admitted for permanent residency. Aliens in the terrorist screening database are deemed inadmissible under Section 212(a)(3)(B)(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, with the exception of those lawfully admitted for permanent residence. Aliens in the terrorist screening database are deemed inadmissible under Section 212(a)(3)(B)(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, except for lawful permanent residents who are not deportable under Section 237(a)(4)(B). Waivers of inadmissibility are available for aliens identified in the terrorist screening database. Section 212(d)(3) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include exceptions for certain individuals identified in the terrorist screening database. Waivers of inadmissibility are available on a case-by-case basis. The amendment to Section 212(d)(3) of the Immigration and Nationality Act allows for exceptions for individuals in the terrorist screening database. The Secretary of Homeland Security can grant nonimmigrant visas on a case-by-case basis for national security interests. The Secretary of Homeland Security may grant a waiver for nonimmigrant visas to individuals in the terrorist screening database with the unanimous concurrence of key officials. SEC. 4. EXPEDITED REMOVAL OF ALIENS INADMISSIBLE OR DEPORTABLE ON SECURITY AND RELATED GROUNDS. Section 238 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include removal of aliens who are not permanent residents and are inadmissible or deportable on security or related grounds. The Secretary of Homeland Security can determine the inadmissibility or deportability of aliens on security grounds and issue removal orders accordingly. The Secretary of Homeland Security can issue removal orders to aliens determined to be inadmissible or deportable on security grounds. The Secretary of Homeland Security can issue removal orders to aliens who are inadmissible or deportable on security grounds, following specific procedures outlined in the law. An alien falls under this category if they have not been granted a waiver under section 212(d)(3)(C) and were not lawfully admitted. The Secretary of Homeland Security can issue removal orders to aliens who are inadmissible or deportable on security grounds, following specific procedures outlined in the law. Proceedings under this subsection, as per section 212(d)(3)(C), are expedited and in accordance with regulations set by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Secretary of Homeland Security shall ensure that aliens issued removal orders are given notice of charges, have the right to legal representation, and can inspect evidence to rebut charges. The alien has the right to choose, inspect evidence, and rebut charges in removal proceedings. It must be confirmed that the correct individual is named in the notice, a record is kept for judicial review, and the final order is not adjudicated by the same person who issues the charges. Judicial review is available for the final order of removal. The Secretary of Homeland Security must wait 14 days before executing any removal order to allow the alien to apply for judicial review. Adjudicated aliens are not eligible for discretionary relief from removal. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICABILITY. This Act and its amendments will take effect upon enactment and apply to all aliens in the terrorist screening database after that date.
